awd_titl_txt: Scaling Up Sustainability Awareness, Impact, and Training within the Materials Science and Engineering Community
awd_abstract_narration:
Materials science will play a pivotal role in solving many of the key challenges our society will continue to face in the coming years, including providing a sustainable supply of energy, water, products, services, transportation, buildings, and public infrastructure. New approaches to sustainable development will require materials researchers who have technical expertise and understand the complex interrelationships between materials science and other disciplines. As the premier professional society for materials researchers, the Materials Research Society (MRS) is well positioned to help materials scientists address these challenges. MRS has been building a robust community of practice in this area for many years. In recognition of the critical and cross-cutting role of sustainability in materials science, MRS established the Focus on Sustainability Subcommittee in 2016. This proposal seeks to build on and expand the scope of sustainability activities and programming within MRS, as well as to increase the impact of sustainability within MRS and beyond to the entire materials science community.

The MRS Focus on Sustainability Subcommittee, along with two task forces, will execute three thrusts including: (1) enhancing awareness and understanding of sustainability across MRS; (2) elevating the impact of sustainability efforts within MRS; and (3) training the next generation of materials scientists to incorporate sustainability in their work.  Awareness and understanding of sustainability will be enhanced by meeting attendee engagement through multiple routes, including gamification, handouts, video, and social media, and a special networking event and program at the 2019 MRS Spring Meeting will seek to engage 140 energy and sustainability symposium organizers in the MRS broader sustainability efforts. The impact of the MRS sustainability efforts will be elevated by building on the successful series of high profile, panel discussions on interdisciplinary sustainability topics, as well as starting a new effort to bring in invited speakers on targeted hot topics that intersect with sustainability. A set of new workshops will train materials scientists to more comprehensively incorporate sustainability in their research. Finally, background research on the current status of sustainability in materials science curricula will inform a longer-term reform effort. Together, these efforts have the potential to increase the role of sustainability in materials science research and to inform new approaches to materials science that more completely take sustainability into account.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to build on and expand the scope of sustainability activities and programming within the Materials Research Society (MRS), as well as to increase the impact of sustainability within MRS and beyond to the entire materials science community. The activities in this project were planned and executed by MRS's Focus on Sustainability Subcommittee and task forces of students and early career professionals - all volunteer groups within this vibrant, member-driven premier professional society of more than 14,500 materials researchers from academia, industry, and government. The project focused on three main areas: enhancing awareness of sustainability and how materials science and related disciplines can contribute, elevating the impact of sustainability efforts, and training the next generation of materials scientists to incorporate sustainability into their work.

Efforts to enhance awareness included organizing a "Sustainability in Action" video competition that invited participants to submit videos that showcase how they are addressing sustainability in their research or on their campuses. The selected video, from the University of Michigan, was screened at the 2022 MRS Fall Meeting. Additional efforts to enhance awareness included updating MRS website content on sustainability and engaging participants through the Focus on Sustainability booth at MRS meetings. Sustainability Engagement Task Force members (mostly students and postdocs) also designed and executed gamification activities through the MRS Meeting app to engage meeting attendees in sustainability surveys and quizzes.

To elevate the impact of sustainability efforts, the MRS Focus on Sustainability Subcommittee continued and enhanced its panel discussion series on the theme "Materials Needs for Energy Sustainability by 2050." Eight interactive moderated panel discussions with experts were held, covering such topics as hydrogen as the fuel of the future, the circular polymer bioeconomy, and long-duration energy storage. When the COVID pandemic paused in-person MRS meetings, a virtual event on "COVID-19 Impacts on Energy and Sustainability Aspects of Materials Supply Chains" was offered. The panel events included live audience polling and networking opportunities, fostering deeper engagement with event attendees, and some panel discussions have been summarized and expanded on in published commentary or perspective articles in MRS Energy & Sustainability.

The project also aimed at training the next generation through workshops like "Designing Sustainability into Materials Research." This workshop taught participants to consider sustainability aspects such as materials availability, reuse, recycling, and environmental and human health impacts in their research. Training efforts also included workshops such as "United Nations Sustainable Development Goals: Agents for Sustainable Community Change," which introduced the UN sustainable development goals and provided tools for creating sustainability action plans to MRS Student Chapter members. Through the project, a survey of the MRS membership was also conducted, along with follow-up interviews, to assess and learn how to enhance sustainability instruction in materials science curricula, gathering valuable insights from faculty, students, and industry professionals. The findings were published in a perspective article in MRS Energy & Sustainability.

Overall, the project activities directly engaged hundreds of materials researchers through in-person and virtual events and workshops, with far more individuals impacted through outreach and networking activities, surveys, and through the availability of published materials. The project successfully expanded sustainability activities within MRS, increased awareness of sustainability in the context of materials science, enhanced the impact of MRS's sustainability efforts, and trained the next generation of materials scientists to incorporate sustainability into their work.
